data.formatted_address: 4 Jing Shan Qian Jie, Dong Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100009
data.name: The Palace Museum

reviews.text:
This is the national museum in china. However the way to enter it is far more complicated. Especially if you are a foreigner.

You need to register 3 days in advance, and get a ticket I guess. We hired a tour guide so everything is settled by them.

Then you will need to pass through a few security checks in order to enter.

Once you enter, there will be a lot of historical stuff to see.
But there are some 3D printed out from them, they just show you the item and the history about it

Overall it is a good experience.

Yes. This place is absolutely worth visiting anytime. Even more times. The bad thing is that the entrance is limited. You have to purchase your tickets one week in advance and it is still not guaranteed that you will buy them. Then you have to purchase them in some “other” ways. Even travel agencies aren't always successful with buying tickets so fingers crossed for you. Once you are inside, the whole area looks just stunning. What they built but how the selected people lived behind the walls to separate from common people who paid for their crazy high lifestyle. Anyway, again it is a good experience to see it on your own. Thank you🤩

The Palace Museum, also known as the Forbidden City, is an awe-inspiring testament to China's rich imperial history and a must-visit landmark in Beijing. As one of the largest and best-preserved ancient wooden structures in the world, it offers a fascinating glimpse into the opulence and grandeur of China's past.

**Architecture and Layout:**
The architecture of the Palace Museum is nothing short of breathtaking. Spanning over 180 acres, the complex features nearly 1,000 buildings with exquisite detailing, vibrant colors, and intricate designs. The symmetry and layout of the palace reflect traditional Chinese cosmology and philosophy, offering a visual feast at every turn.

**Exhibits and Collections:**
The museum houses an extensive collection of over 1.8 million artifacts, including priceless treasures such as ancient paintings, ceramics, jade, and royal garments. Each exhibit tells a story of the palace’s past, from the daily lives of emperors to the ceremonial rituals that took place within its walls. Special exhibitions often rotate, showcasing different aspects of Chinese culture and history.

**Cultural and Historical Significance:**
Walking through the vast courtyards and halls, one can feel the weight of history. The Palace Museum was the political and ceremonial center of Chinese dynasties for almost 500 years, and its preservation allows visitors to step back in time and experience the grandeur of imperial China. It's a place where the cultural heritage of China is meticulously preserved and presented to the world.

**Visitor Experience:**
The Palace Museum is well-organized and provides a wealth of information for visitors. Audio guides and multilingual signage enhance the experience, making it easy to learn about the historical significance of each area. However, due to its popularity, the site can get very crowded, especially during peak tourist seasons, so it's advisable to visit early in the day or during off-peak times.

**Practical Tips:**
- Wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of walking involved.
- Allocate at least half a day to fully explore the site.
- Pre-book tickets online to avoid long queues.

**Conclusion:**
The Palace Museum in Beijing is more than just a historical site; it is a journey through time that offers a profound insight into China's imperial past. Whether you are a history enthusiast, a lover of architecture, or simply a curious traveler, a visit to the Palace Museum is an unforgettable experience that leaves you with a deep appreciation for China's rich cultural legacy.

It'll be your 100% loss if you go Beijing without visiting The Palace Museum.
Immersing in ancient China histories at the Palace, with local guided tour, listening to stories regarding each corner of this palace, touching building with thousands years of history.
Didn't go during peak season so the crowds is still okay.
I will come here again if I have the chance to visit Beijing another time!

Not sure why it is said to be so expensive, it is actually 60 RNB to get in, that is if you can get the tickets to get in, as for a foreigner alone it is almost impossible 🙅. Now once you get the ticket you have two scenarios, either you are amazed by the massive structure of the palace and its buildings, or you are let down by your expectation, as around 50-60% of the palace and most of the interiors is closed to the public. I was more on the second one, even though I loved and remained amazed by some of it, I also felt like let down, as I was expecting to be able to visit the old crannies and narrow street of the palace. That is unfortunately not possible and it seems like it is not going to be anymore… I was considering 3/5 star but it wouldn’t be fair to the history and experience of the place, I will still add 4/5 but don’t have high expectations of it.

data.formatted_address: Yanqing District, China, 102112
data.name: Great Wall of Badaling

reviews.text:
I recently visited the Badaling section of the Great Wall of China, and it was truly an amazing experience. The views of the mountains are breathtaking, and seeing the wall built with limited technology on such rugged terrain changes your entire perspective. It's mind-blowing.

The area is very well-maintained and clean. Although we visited on a weekend and it was quite crowded, the experience was still enjoyable. The souvenir shops and restaurants were nice, you have a lot of options to choose from.

Navigating the area was relatively easy thanks to good signage, but I recommend doing some research before you go. Be prepared to walk a lot and tackle some seriously steep stairs.

Overall, every part of the visit was memorable. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Beijing.

Absolutely amazing to re-visit the most famous great wall together with my American friends in their 80’s!   I was a teenager last time when I was walking up this part of the Great Wall together with my parents…

It was almost 100 degree Fahrenheit, but we loved walking up the steps.  So many Chinese - my country peers were friendly with us and even tried to help out my senior friends by offering them umbrella or water, etc.

65 years up seniors are waived with entrance tickets, regardless of nationalities.

Imagine it’s 8k kilometers long, and after 2hrs of walking, we only ended up only finished 1.5km of distance!

No wonder this is one of the world’s 7 wonders!    👍 👍

Make sure to book your ticket earlier a day or two before. Come early in the morning

Open 8am until 430pm everyday.

Crowded on weekends, better go on weekedays. Use train to reach the badaling train station.

Be mentally prepare to climb and bring umbrella in got small child.

A must visit historical spot for every tourist to Beijing. We planned the visit during the off peak season, thus everything was smooth and easy.
Taking the car from Beijing to the Badaling took us about 90 minutes, it all depends on the traffic condition. Although it is during winter, we were so lucky to have sunny weather.
For visitors with elderly and kids, or health disabilities, it is advised to take the cable car. There is still a short climb to the peak of Badaling Great wall but it was manageable for most healthy people. It is a very steep climb.
It is very crowded at the peak, but worth it to pay a visit. You can have a nice view of the surrounding and see the Great wall extend far into the mountainous area. It is a magnificent view and touched to realize that the ancient Chinese spent thousands of years building this wall preventing the intruder from the north.
The best photo spot isn't at the peak but a trench of a great wall nearby. It has a great view under the morning sun.
Taking the cable car will help to save you a lot of time and you will be able to complete the visit to the top within an hour or less. But if you would like to enjoy the full experience of Great wall climb, I believe you can enjoy more on foot.

Badaling is well developed for tourists. You may take any of the convenient transportations like high speed rail, train or tour bus from city. Pay extra at entrance for cable car to get up to the Great Wall platform #4, west side to stations # 2 & #3 gives you a flavor of hiking; east side to stations #7 are flat, easy walks.

data.formatted_address: W96X+JXR, Dongcheng, Beijing, China, 100006
data.name: Imperial Ancestral Temple

reviews.text:
The Imperial Ancestral Temple, or Taimiao (simplified Chinese: 太庙; traditional Chinese: 太廟; pinyin: Tàimiào) of Beijing, is a historic site in the Imperial City, just outside the Forbidden City, where during both the Ming and Qing Dynasties, sacrificial ceremonies were held on the most important festival occasions in honor of the imperial family's ancestors.[1]

Imperial Ancestral Temple

太廟

￼

The Hall for Worship of Ancestors

￼

Wikimedia | © OpenStreetMap

General informationLocationImperial CityEstimated completion1420 (18th year of Yongle Emperor)

The temple, which resembles the Forbidden City's ground plan, is a cluster of buildings in three large courtyards separated by walls. The main hall inside the temple is the Hall for Worship of Ancestors, which is one of only four buildings in Beijing to stand on a three-tiered platform, a hint that it was the most sacred site in imperial Beijing. It contains seats and beds for the tablets of emperors and empresses, as well as incense burners and offerings. On the occasion of large-scale ceremonies for worship of ancestors, the emperors would come here to participate.

Flanking the courtyard in front of this hall are two long, narrow buildings. These were worship halls for various princes and courtiers. The Western Wing housed the spirit tablets of meritorious courtiers, while the Eastern Wing enshrined various princes of the Ming or Qing dynasty.

Behind the Hall for Worship of Ancestors are two other main halls. The first was built in 1420 and used to store imperial spirit tablets.

By the 1920s, the Imperial Ancestral Temple and its surrounding spaces had become a public park, and that public park today has been expanded from its original size and is now also known as the Working People's Cultural Palace (劳动人民文化宫; pinyin: Láodòng Rénmín Wénhuà Gōng). This park was extended based on the Imperial Ancestral Hall site, and the park is located east of Tiananmen, while the Zhongshan Park lies to the west. These two parks along with Beihai Park and Jingshan and several other parks have a deep historic tie with the Forbidden City.

It is nice for a walk but nothing special. We are here at weekend and during holidays what makes place crowded. Reason for having only three stars is that entrance to the temple is not included in the ticket. Therefore you have to go to ticket office and back, costs additional 15 yuans.
amazing architecture and ancient historic museum, you will need to walk a lot, but it worth the experience.

Located inside Tiananmen gate a stones throw from the Forbidden City, it feels like you are a world away from the throngs of tourists and the chaos that is the Forbidden City. This place has a ton of history, serving as a temple to many past emperors, and the architecture is impressive both in its scale and beauty. The cost to get in is only 2 kuai (less than 30 cents US) and when we went there was hardly a soul to be seen. If you go to the Forbidden City, make sure you stop inside this place before going through (or after coming out of) the Meridian Gate. You won't regret it
Absolutely amazing, it is very busy here make sure you take a book or audio book if not can be difficult to know what your looking at.

data.formatted_address: 前门 Dongcheng, China, 100051
data.name: Tiananmen Square

reviews.text: It is definitely a must-visit historical place for obvious reasons. However, it is a bit annoying to go through all the checkpoints. In total, I had to show my passport 8 times while navigating through different gates. The wait time in the queues is also considerably long. Probably not the best place to visit on a hot summer day, but otherwise, due to its historical value, it's worth visiting.

Book one day before. To get to the place, if you stay around the Wangfujing area, walking to this place is possible. Taxi dropoff at the premise is not possible, so you have to ask to be dropped off about almost a kilometer away from the gate.

If you have booked, once dropped off, walk a bit and ready for a few security checkpoints and these will take some of your time visiting the place. Overall, worth the wait, majestic and full of wonderful histories.

One of main landmarks in Beijing. Impressively large square. But overall not much to do or see here, except you want to visit the museum inside. I’ll give one star less because it takes way too long to get in … long lines, endless ID checks and security lanes. Plan at least 40min before you get in the square.. and you have to walk fat from drop-off and pick up points to get a taxi.

Must-visit place in the center of Beijing. Open square with famous monuments from the old and the new China. With now doubt it is part of the living history of the country. In summer, do not go at midday or early afternoon as with all the concrete it might get to hot.

Tiananmen Square is a main tourist attraction in Beijing for foreigners and Chinese people too. The Great Hall of People and Mao’s Mausoleum are located around. Be prepared that it’s a security fortress - bring your passport and booking an appointment in advance could be required. It’s worth to visit.

reviews.text:
Eva, our guide from China Highlights, used the Temple of Heaven as a mini-guide to Chinese feng shui and symbolism, pointing out all of the little details on the Temple and its surrounding buildings.

It's a beautiful place, and full of fascinating history. There are English placards around that give some insight as to each building's purpose. There isn't much in the way of shade in the actual temple, though, so wear sunscreen and bring plenty of water.
Very nice place to visit. Take your passport with you.

It's a huge historical complex where you can easily spend several hours. Besides temple of heaven, there are several small temples. Then there is pathways, where people are sitting and paying board games, and large gardens round buildings.
History site that is for sure worth a visit
Iconic symbol of Beijing.

reviews.text: If you want some adrenaline rush... this the perfect place. A lot of roller-coaster rides.. Try to plan visit in summers... couple of rides closed during winter. KFC and other fast food stalls inside. No worries about in-house food or lunch

The sound, lights, costumes, acting, dances and water flow effects are beyond words. If you visit Beijing, don’t miss this epic show.
Good n memorable spectacular show . Recommend to go n watch

Awesome Stuff & Place .. Love it so much I spend all the day and not finishing all Games but some games the Line very long but Great waiting with Chinese people Love them

reviews.text: Cost us 20rmb each to enter this huge park. We only completed the main circle and did not go to the outer one as we were just too tired from the earlier forbidden city walk. But it was nice stroll around the park.
Beautiful lake where you can relax by walking along it when the weather is nice. Lot of women walking in traditional dresses… Lovely atmosphere, quiet…

Beihai Park in Beijing is a stunning oasis amidst the bustling city. Its serene lakes, lush greenery, and historic architecture create a picturesque setting that's truly enchanting. Walking along the winding pathways, you're treated to breathtaking views of ancient pagodas, intricate bridges, and traditional Chinese gardens. The tranquility of the park offers a welcome escape from the urban chaos, allowing visitors to immerse themselves in the beauty of nature and culture. Whether you're strolling by the water's edge, admiring the colorful foliage, or exploring the historical landmarks, Beihai Park captivates with its timeless charm and serene ambiance. It's a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a peaceful retreat in the heart of Beijing.

Another large and popular spot in Beijing to wander around for hours! Stunning views throughout the park!

Prepare your passport and a form of payment such as AliPay or WeChat Pay.

Short video to get an idea of what to expect starting at 5:25 - 6:50. https://youtu.be/hZ9MHLyjuoQ
The entrance fee for the park is 5rmb. You can pay an extra fee to enter the White Dagoba and the other temple. It’s worth a short visit 😊 (visited on 9Nov, noon)

data.formatted_address: China, Bei Jing Shi, Xi Cheng Qu, 西直门外大街137号 邮政编码: 100044
data.name: Beijing Zoo

reviews.text:
While the zoo was huge, the animals really had almost zero welfare. While we were there, the elephants were in miserable condition & were banging themselves against the enclosure out of frustrations. The chimpanzees weren’t doing any better. They are social creatures, but they were all locked individually in small areas leading to frustrations, banging against the door & screams.

The security didn’t do much to stop visitors from urinating in public, flashing the other animals & there was even a child with a water gun shooting water at the animals. I mean, who goes to the zoo with a water gun unless the intention was already there?!

Only the pandas really had any kind of welfare. I won’t pay to support this zoo again. I can easily see pandas elsewhere.

Amazing Experience!!!! Never been to such a large Zoo in my life, many animals, big parc with garden to walk around! I’ve spent more than 3 Hours around ! Loved it fully!! Do I have to say the Panda were awesome!!!!🤩 So many animals, they looked very well cared!!!

Enjoyed the panda enclosure. The rest of the zoo is nothing special.

The worst is the elephants enclosure. Our hearts were broken because of the elephants enclosure. The elephants were all in distress.  Some were banging at the door/fence, and some were going in circles in the tiny enclosure. Very very poor things. There were no photos taken as we were rushing out. It's just too unbearable to watch the poor elephants.

We dare not step into the giraffe enclosure as the building looked similar to the elephants' enclosure building structure.

Sigh. Hope the animals are locked in the building due to cold weather (early December) and not animal abuse.

The Zoo is outdated and in a very bad state: all buildings and enclosures are very dirty, cages and fences are rusty, a few zones are completely closed. The most disappointing zoo I've ever seen.

If you visit it on a public holiday, be prepared that it's very crowded and takes around 10 min to get inside and around 30 to get to the great pandas. Buy tickets in advance via WeChat miniapp (you need someone with a China Mainland phone number for the booking).
Actually a nice Zoo in the center of Beijing. Pretty fun for spending a weekend. It feels good here.

data.formatted_address: 44 Jing Shan Xi Jie, 景山 Xi Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100009
data.name: Jingshan Park

reviews.text: The royal hill garden north of the imperial palace. A good vantage point to oversee the palace. Came on a Sunday and it is sure crowded. It’s good if you have a good camera for distant shots else with an iPhone, the photos dun really look great. It’s a must come attraction in Beijing. I feel in snow, the palace photos will definitely look great shooting from this height.

Amazing park behind the Forbidden City, with a hill full of traditional buildings on it, from where you can get amazing views of Beijing (to all its cardinal points), and in particular of the Forbidden City. You can also see beautiful sunsets, so I suggest visiting in late afternoon/evening.

The garden is pretty quiet and beautiful. The best part though is the absolutely breathtaking views of the Fobidden City from the top of the hill (not too long of a walk). It costs ¥2 (chinese yuan) which is nothing. The entrance is right opposite of the north gate of the fobidden city. 100% recommended especially if you didn’t manage to get tickets for the Forbidden City!
Park that is opposite the forbidden city. We got our tickets onsite as we do not have a local mainland number to get it on WeChat. Climb up the hill to get a Birds Eye view of the forbidden city!

Located at the back of the forbidden palace is jingshan park. You can buy tickets on the spot for a small price and get a panoramic view of the forbidden palace below. Recommended to come during sunset when you are done exploring the palace below. It’s quite a few steps up the hill but you are free to rest along the way as the paths are rather wide. Crowds are considered manageable.

reviews.text:
Easy to get to the temple by bus and subway. Feel like visiting in the forest and ancient temple in highland of Tibet, but the temple is located in downtown area.

There are many shops and restaurants nearby. Ticket is sold at the office in front of the temple. So, you don’t need to buy a ticket in advance.

Should visit this temple, if you travel in Beijing.

Reached here around 1525hrs on a weekday. Not too crowded. Do note they closed at 4.30pm. They offer incense sticks inside so dun need to buy. Supposed to be 3 sticks for each urn but I was left with even number of incense sticks before leaving?
Heard that this temple is true in granting wishes just that not in your way from online sources. Anyway it’s a beautiful temple and not all places u can take photos. There is a large standing Tibetian Buddha statue 3 storey high housed inside a building. It’s really magnificent but no photos allowed. U can buy your tickets here but I bought mine on WeChat.

The Lama Temple, also known as Yonghe Temple (雍和宫), is one of the most important Tibetan Buddhist temples in China. When we visited, we saw many devotees praying and offering incense sticks, which are available for free at the temple. The incense sticks are used to create a sacred and serene atmosphere, as well as to honor the deities and ancestors.

A really worth visit place. It will be perfect if all the trees along the way are blooming. Too bad i visited at a non peak season. Besides this is one of the few place i think that ppl will automatically keep there clean

The most important Buddhist temple outside the Tibet.
Its very well preserved and its impressive to see it in use with the monks praying.
At the entrance they give free incense, and the idea is to put three sticks in front of the different Buddhas.

It’s very crowded, so it’s hard to appreciate or take pictures without people.

There is a huge line in the morning to go in, better go later in the day.

There is a ticket office next to the entrance you don’t need to buy them in advance.

data.formatted_address: J6XV+HH9, Miyun District, Beijing, China, 101508
data.name: 司马台长城

reviews.text: Our family finally climbed the Wall Easter 2023. The magnificent of the Wall over the mountains and hills arguably is one of the most unforgettable things we have done over the years. This part of the wall is challenging enough but not overly so. Our agent, China Highlight, originally suggested going from Jianjou to Mutianyu, I think four would start and only two or less would return 🤣🤣, so Simatai is more suitable. Some parts were pretty steep and slippery but manageable. The day we were there the Wall was not crowded at all, we saw, probably, less than 30 people as we descended from Tower 8 back to the base where we took the cable car up. Wonderful experience and HIGHLY recommended. the only thing is…pick a day that is not rainy.

Best choice for the great wall segment! Very little human crowd as noise for pictures taken. Best to take the cable car up one way and walk all the way down! This segment of the great wall has not much up and downs. Once you're up it's essentially descending all the way. But the steps are narrow and treacherous. More suitable for the young and healthy to scale. They have an option to tour the great wall at night as well. For that i think it's bettwe to just take cable car up and down just to see the scenery. For climbing, still seems safer in the day

This is a part of the Great Wall, it is not like other parts of the Great Wall which is well-repaired, this one has the shortest wall of all the Walls. There’s two ways to get up to the Great Wall, one is by the trial in day time, the other is by cable car in night time. Most visitors here are for the unique night visit, which can’t be done in other places, it is truly worth the price and time to be on the Great wall at night. In my opinion, the best time to get up the Wall is around 5 pm to 6 pm, watching the sunset and the mountain view, and when it turns dark, it’s time for the famous night visit.

Such an amazing view :)
Walking distance from 古北水鎮 and there is a rope way that you can ride and takes you to quite a near by( so no need to climb too much).

What a beautiful part of the Great Wall to see. Not a ton of people, semi restored, and a lift just in case you can't / don't want to climb. There is a nice town at the entrance but its pretty touristy. In that it was pretty much rebuilt for tourism. It can be a difficult part of the wall to get to but they recently started a bus that goes directly to Simatai from DongZhimen. It cost 48 CNY one way and is about 2 1/2 hours. The tricky part is finding where the bus is so you may have to ask around a bit. The times are limited so do your research. I also suggest you reserve your ticket online for the wall. The cost for the wall is only 40 CNY but those tickets are limited. There is another ticket that is 170 CNY that includes access to the little water town and the wall but I feel it's a bit of a rip off. Also, please note that the bus back to DongZhimen is also limited. When you get to the water town reserve a spot for the bus and be on time or it will leave you or give your seat to someone else. There are 3 different places for tickets. The parking lot has a ticket office (kinda) for the bus. This is the same place to store luggage. There is the main ticket office that is in a huge building by a water fountain. They only sell the combined tickets. If you walk past the fountain with it and the main building on your right you'll go through an archway (I think) there will be another ticket office there for tickets just for the wall. If you think that's complicated well, welcome to China.

data.formatted_address: 20 Qian Men Dong Da Jie, Dong Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100051
data.name: Beijing Planning Exhibition Hall

reviews.text: is ok but But Beijing deserves a better one.

It's 150 m walk from exit B of the Qianmen metro station on line 2. Gate fee is 30 RMB. The museum spans 4 floors. English is sparse. The exhibits did not provide good outline of Beijing city planning. Most exhibits stood alone without any focus on how either a city mandate or technology advancement pushed the city forward. For example, there was an animated visual of the evolution of transportation. There was no explanation of the replacement of the sedan chair to the modern speed trains increased the number passengers. We know this intuitively, but numbers and facts helps drive the point. This was the case for a lot of the displays. Many of the movie show times were not running. The 1:750 scale model of Beijing is really cool. The museum needs a refreshed modern look and service.

There was a giant miniature city (as you can see in the pictures) which looked really cool. It was really detailed and probably took soo long to make. It was also really informative about Beijing's past, present, and future.

The Beijing City Planning Hall, official name Beijing Urban Planning Exhibition Hall, is located in the southeast corner of the famous Tiananmen Square. Opened to the public on Sep.9th, 2004, it is one of the AAAA scenic spots in Beijing. The Beijing City Planning Hall was rebuilt on the basis of the former well-known Front Gate Shopping Mall. Since its opening, it has received more than 4 million visitors from home and abroad, including the paramount leaders in China and dignitaries from more than 90 countries. The Beijing City Planning Hall is one of the best places to know the long history of Beijing, which showcases the great achievements of Beijing urban planning construction, as well as the future development. For example, because there used to be a height limit on the buildings in Beijing, so virtually there are very few skyscrapers in the city. The highest building in Beijing right now is only 330 meters high and located in CBD. A new building called China of Honor is being built in CBD now, which is going to be 528 meters in height in 2016. Visitors could see its model on the second floor of the Exhibition Hall. With a floor space of 16,000 square meters and exhibition area of 8,000 square meters, the 4-storey Exhibition Hall is also playing a role as the patriotism-education base as well as a platform for the international experts and scholars to exchange ideas.
Literally a govt funded SimCity. I've never been within 5000 miles of this place in my life. Amazing.

data.formatted_address: 2 Xi Chang An Jie, Xi Cheng Qu, China, 100031
data.name: National Centre for the Performing Arts

reviews.text: Definitely, this is a masterpiece in terms of design, structural engineering and architecture. Simplicity at its end. Exquisite finishing materials, everything is matching perfectly in details and textures, marble, wood, light and shadows, gloss and soft surfaces. Amazing dimensions of internal space, huge opening horizontal and vertical as well, curves playfulness, impressive sample of new China architecture. In the end, I highly recommend this genuine unique building for a unique space exploration.
Such a beautiful building, Nice to see in the evening. We went to a dance performance to see the inside. Well worth s visit!

It was beautiful at night.
The colour was changing every few seconds.
Great facility and awesome show

Went there for a classical orchestral performance, shocked to see that the ushers used laser pointers to shine at patrons' eyes to get their attention to stop taking pictures/videos!! I went to speak to the management, who obviously did not take me seriously and defended their actions, basically saying they will continue to do it. Just when you think China is getting advanced, a prominent national venue like this proves you otherwise. Behaviour of an undeveloped country!

data.name: National Museum of China

reviews.text: Free entry but you need a ticket to enter! There is a crowd to enter the museum.. took us 20 mins to enter after all the bag and human checks. Main attraction is in the basement which tells you the history of China. The place is horribly big so be prepared to walk and walk!

Went there on 14 Nov, appointment is needed, you can do via WeChat, very convenient in China. This museum is super huge comparing to the very few museums I went to. You can easily spend half a day there. I was in rush, if I have the chance to revisit Beijing, I would definitely go back to learn more about the arts, history and culture. 🫶🏻🇨🇳

Biggest museum I ever been. There's so much to see and a few hours is definitely not enough to see all of it. You have to do booking in WeChat to visit this museum. This museum is strict with the security, no selfie stick is allowed. Kindly view the rules and regulations before entering the museum.

Visited in November 2023. Fantastic journey into history - as expected from a top 3 museum in China - the quantity and quality of exhibits transports one back in time.

Mandatory to reserve in advance though it’s free. Booked tickets via WeChat app mini program. Be patient - if it doesn’t work / go through first time, try again (as with many China based apps - persistence pays off).

Security checks to enter premises are efficient. All national Monuments close on Monday so plan around this.
Very impressive place to learn a lot about Chinese history. The museum covers many different areas of Chinese culture. You can spend many hours in there.

data.formatted_address: 8XVP+6V4, Yanqing District, Beijing, China, 102112
data.name: Badaling Caritive Great Wall Natural Scenic Area

reviews.text: Not the popular spot to climb the wall but the rolling green hills were gorgeous

There are several different points of access to the Great Wall of China, we reached the Badaling gate. The tour guide said that this place has the highest and widest panorama. You can go up to the wall by cable car and the view is beautiful. Since I haven't seen the other doors, I can't claim that this one is the best, but at least you can get an idea with the pictures I shared. There is also a small but organized market here where you can find ethnic products.

Visited Badaling Great Wall twice. The second time was on a Sunday, in the spring of March 2019. What a horror. The entire Chinese wall turns into a river of people. In places where the passage narrows and steps down, traffic jams form. In a place where you need to walk through a narrow passage in a tower, people with a fear of closed spaces may become hysterical. I was lucky the first time there were five times fewer people and I was able to walk normally along the wall, I climbed quite far. In general, you need to come in the off-season or on weekdays. The most important thing is, under no circumstances go to the so-called. Safari park near the wall. This is a wretched place in every way!

The Badaling Ancient Great Wall Scenic Area is just one word different from the Badaling Great Wall, but they are actually two different scenic spots. Compared with the famous Badaling Great Wall, this scenic spot has much fewer tourists. The transportation is not very convenient: after taking 919 to the Badaling Ancient Great Wall Station, you have to walk 1,500 meters to the gate of the scenic spot, and then you have to walk more than one kilometer to the entrance to the city. If you drive by yourself, it seems that it will be much more convenient if you can drive to a place not far from the city. You can see the ruins at the top of the city, which are said to be the original ruins where Li Zicheng broke through the pass. There are ruins on the east and west sides of the Great Wall, and the scenic road is the western section. There are 7 beacon towers on the scenic area. In fact, after passing the fourth beacon tower, there will be a reminder to tell the scenic area. I didn’t notice the prompt at first (I only saw it on my way back), and there were no fences in the scenic area, so I kept walking forward. The Great Wall outside the scenic area is also in good repair. We went straight to the highest point (it seems to be called "Qingshui Summit") and then turned back. The section of the Great Wall to the east of the ruins is not open to the public. It is actually a crossing route. Along this section of the Great Wall, you can pass by the beast area of ​​the Badaling Wildlife Park and then cross to the Badaling Scenic Area. There are quite a few cliffs that are difficult to navigate, so outdoor novices should try it carefully.
very impressive!

data.formatted_address: 338Q+6GG, Haidian District, Beijing, China, 100095
data.name: Jiufeng National Forest Park

reviews.text:
I've been to Jiufeng probably a few decades ago. At that time, it was an unmanaged wild mountain. I often passed by it and didn't come to play much. I didn't climb to the top many times and it wasn't difficult. There are so many mountains in Haidian that you don't need to run this much. Coming from afar, this is a good starting point for hikers. There is the Jiufeng Ancient Temple here, which is now a hotel. The scenery inside is good. When the weather is nice, you can go in and drink tea under the ancient trees. It is better and cheaper than Dajue Temple. There is a seismic observatory built during the Republic of China. It is said to be the first seismic observatory in China. You can visit it.
The red leaves and ginkgo trees here are very beautiful every autumn after November. Be sure not to come here on weekends, as there will still be traffic jams here.

The classic route for outdoor activities, Balcony Mountain + Jiufeng.

I really want to take a suburban car again, go to Baihu Stream, cross Fenghuang Ridge to Jiufeng, and go all the way down the mountain. I have walked through Jiulong Mountain many times, from Xiangshan to Badachu, Lingshan in the Rain, Xiaowutai, and Xiangshan, not to mention Xiangshan. I can’t count how many times I have walked there.
I really miss you, my mountain friends and team leaders who have walked together. We use the mobile phone to copy the conversations of mountain friends and sing on the mobile phone! Thank you 🙏 for accompanying me through my young years. Slowly turn physical movement into mechanical movement. I think the person I looked down upon the most back then was the little boy in the gym [laughing][laughing]
Now scattered, I wonder if the great people back then are still great now and still have the same persistence in their respective lives.
I miss the green fields and the spirit of the green fields. Playing outdoors was not fashionable at that time, but it was the most practical step for us.
It feels so good to look at those photos now! Enjoy life, enjoy the truth, enjoy the young heart.
I miss you so much, the friends who have walked together in my life. It seems like yesterday we were gathering at the entrance of the Xiangshan Clinic! It’s like I’m still the leader [laughing] running at the front, smiling brightly and enjoying my unrestrained mind!
On the way to chase my dreams, I have not drifted away, but I have passed you by! If possible, I really want to get together with you again and see each other as a mark of remembrance! ——Hawa Gecha

The mountain road next to Dajue Temple detours into Wufeng Park. The mountain road in the park is still relatively primitive. It was an ancient trail in the past, and the view is good when you climb to a high place.
In spring, you can go to the Plum Blossom Greenhouse to see plum blossoms.
The mountain is very high, very challenging, there are few people, and the plants are lush. It is a good place for aerobic exercise.

data.formatted_address: 19 Xin Jian Gong Men Lu, Hai Dian Qu, China, 100091
data.name: Summer Palace

reviews.text:
It is a must-visit in Beijing. I went on a sunny warm day in early May. It was very full of locals as it was extended weekend of Labor Day. That made my visit a bit uncomfortable as they were thousands and thousands of people all around.
Architecture of the Summer Palace is amazing and it is full of history.
I used East and South-East entrance. Even in public holiday and nice weather, I didn’t have to wait more than 10 minutes to get tickets, which are affordable and worth the expense.
There are nice paths and bridges to walk in quiet; also the lake is beautiful.
I strongly suggest to pay the integrated ticket that allows you to see all attractions inside, as the Hall of the See of Wisdom and its Thousand-Hand Buddha Statue are amazing!!!

Exploring the Summer Palace in Beijing offers an incredible experience, immersing you in the grandeur of ancient Chinese architecture and serene natural beauty. Wander through this expansive imperial garden and be captivated by its picturesque landscape, tranquil lakes, and intricately designed pavilions and halls. Stroll along the Long Corridor, adorned with vibrant paintings, and admire the iconic Marble Boat floating on Kunming Lake. Climb to the top of Longevity Hill for breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding area. Be sure to explore the various temples, bridges, and pagodas scattered throughout the palace grounds. Whether you're fascinated by history, seeking a peaceful escape, or want to admire stunning architecture, a visit to the Summer Palace is a must for any traveler in Beijing.
by: dizzy traveler

This was the garden for the mother of the emperor. The total size is even bigger than the forbidden city. The lake is connected to the forbidden city though

It is advice you spend at least half day there as it is too big to finish all. If you want to take the boat to do a tour on the lake, you have to buy another ticket.

It is very beautiful there however what you seen there might not be the original as some of it was damaged and recovered by the gov.

Overall one of the must see places in Beijing. Recommended!!

Prepare for a long walk. Yes it's beautiful and worth the visit. The palace grounds are huge to see it all is quite a trek. Many of the buildings are closed and the upkeep is lacking in a lot of areas. The crowds can be intense even in winter. While we did not have a tour guide, I got a chance to listen to a few. Nothing I heard was very interesting and they seemed to distract from the environment more than benefit, so maybe skip one. Also this park was by far the dirtiest of the historic sites. I'm not sure why but there was a lot of trash scattered around especially in the water. The boats and the boathouses showed the most disrepair of the whole site. Go defiantly go but don't set your expectations too high.

This palace was built upon a hill facing a lake. Felt breeze while walking on the lawyers of buildings demonstrating their splendor, uniqueness and magnificence. It’s truly a summer palace for getaway. Come here early once door opened to avoid crowds. Order tickets online. We stopped by their restaurant for morning coffee tea break: delicious tea, desserts and various sweet soups. The lady even did a quick hairdo for our girls. We also saw an artist writing Chinese choreography on the floor.

data.formatted_address: X9VV+PF8, Chaoyang, China, 100875
data.name: Beijing Olympic Park

reviews.text: Beijing Olympic Park is a must-visit! The park is vast and beautifully maintained, offering a perfect blend of modern architecture and natural beauty. The Bird's Nest stadium and Water Cube are stunning, especially when lit up at night. It's a great place for a leisurely walk, jogging, or simply enjoying the scenery. Highly recommend for both tourists and locals!

Very nice architecture building and nice surroundings too.
You can buy the ticket in the area, they also provide a tour guide to explain the building too.

The arena stadium and the swimming pool was beautifully lit and perfect for pictures in the evening. You can actually purchase tickets to enter the stadium during the day.

The construction of the swimming pool was especially interesting because the outside is constructed with solid glass/material while the inside layer is soft plastic, with air constantly pumped in, to create the bubble looking appearance!

The Olympic Park is a hub of sports activities, including football, swimming, tennis, and badminton. The standout feature, especially at night, is the mesmerizing blue cube with a water-like flow on its outer surface. The main stadium, resembling a bird's nest, is a must-visit. Adjacent to the stadium, you'll find quaint shops offering souvenirs at unbeatable prices. Take advantage of the multilingual shop assistants to bargain effectively – I managed to get one free item with the purchase of five. Don't miss out on this opportunity!

Being in the presence of such architectural marvels as the "Bird's Nest, and the Ice Cube" filled me with a sense of amazement and inspiration. These architectural marvels, born from the dreams of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, continue to captivate visitors with their sheer scale, intricate designs and symbolic significance.

reviews.text: Specifically asked to be taken to this 9 dragon wall and was not disappointed.  If you love Chinese antiquities, you will love this one.  I loved it so much, I am taking a friend of mine to it on their first trip to Beijing.  Really like the 3D effect.

It is exactly what it is, and will not disappoint as long as you are coming for the entire pack. It is but one of the many items around the park should you choose to explore. Worth spending a quiet afternoon there but not if you're in a rush.

Houhai area Beijing it’s so beautiful in all season spring and autumn my favorite you can take boat and enjoy nice weather , in the winter ice ski ting

data.formatted_address: 1 Tian Tan Dong Lu, Dong Cheng Qu, China, 100061
data.name: Temple of Heaven

reviews.text:
Magnificent!!

The place draws such a huge crowd and people even dressed you for it - the traditional costumes.

I've visited Egypt before but this is just amazing. The deep history behind it truly remarkable.

ShangDi or also refer to as the Supreme Ruler (but also known as the UNKNOWN GOD) where the emperor offers sacrifice annually - it began from 1640 until 1911.

Don't miss the place if you're in Beijing.

🙂👍💯

The most beautiful temple in the whole of Beijing. Unfortunately, we came on Monday and the temple was closed. Just like every Monday🤷‍♂️
At least the surrounding park was open and we can walk around. It is absolutely worth visiting the temple, so be sure it is not Monday and get your ticket at the gate. You won't regret it. Thank you🤩

Beautiful architecture, very extensive park but very few benches to take a rest, and maintenance of the plants and shrubs seemed to be lacking when I was there. Relatively moderate crowds (this was a Monday). Entrance to the park is open everyday with a fee (except for visitors above age 60 who get free admission - just show your passport if you're a non-Chinese citizen). However, entry to the historical buildings is closed on Mondays, but you can still appreciate a fair bit of the buildings from the outside of the walls. Entrance is right next to the Temple of Heaven East Gate station (天坛东门站).

The Temple of Heaven in Beijing is a breathtaking marvel of Chinese architecture and history. Its vibrant colors and intricate details are awe-inspiring. Note: Closed on Mondays, so plan accordingly for an unforgettable visit!

On the south side of forbidden city, this temple was a place for emperor annual worship to heaven. The temple itself is the focal point, surrounding and back buildings are painted with traditional royal colors blue, gold and red. Enjoy the awe and solitude while walking along the corridors.

data.formatted_address: 4 Jing Shan Qian Jie, Dong Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100009
data.name: Forbidden City

reviews.text: The Forbidden City is a must-see historical site in Beijing. Its vast complex showcases stunning imperial architecture, with intricate details and vibrant colors. The history is palpable as you walk through the halls and courtyards where emperors once resided. It's a captivating glimpse into China's rich past.

Our family recently explored the Forbidden City in Beijing, and it was an experience we'll always treasure. The Forbidden City's historical significance and grandeur surpassed our expectations.

One of the highlights of our visit was the stunning architecture and intricate details found throughout the Forbidden City. From the majestic gates to the ornate halls and courtyards, every corner was a testament to China's rich cultural heritage and imperial history.

Despite being a popular tourist destination, we were pleasantly surprised by how well-preserved and spacious the Forbidden City felt. Despite the crowds, we were able to navigate through the vast complex at our own pace, taking in the grandeur and imagining the lives of emperors and empresses who once walked these hallowed grounds.

The accessibility of the Forbidden City was another positive aspect of our visit. The well-organized entrances and signage made it easy for us to explore the various sections and learn about China's imperial past.

Overall, our visit to the Forbidden City was nothing short of mesmerizing. It provided us with a glimpse into China's rich history and cultural heritage, leaving us with memories that will last a lifetime. It's a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Beijing and seeking to delve into the heart of China's imperial legacy.

Really amazing attraction to visit if you're in Beijing. Tickets need to be purchased well in advance and recommend getting an English speaking guide. You can rent the automated guide but doesnt seem to work 100%. Not much food options, so be sure to have a good meal before heading over.

Should take around 4 to 6 hours to comfortably cover the entire place. Some sections need to purchase additional tickets, but its pretty reasonably priced.

Stunning visit to the Forbidden City, it's hard to describe the scale of this place. There's a near endless set of amazing structures to view along with huge displays of artefacts from throughout history. We were lucky to go during "off season" so whilst busy it wasn't too chaotic. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Beijing, you'll need to buy tickets online before hand and be prepared for a lot of walking!

Nice history sightseeing, but i don't recommend you to go in summer, especially when it's too hot.

You can walk into the ticket counter in the area or join a 4 hour tour package with a tour guide who explains to you everything about the place.

data.name: 798 Art Zone

reviews.text: The 798 Art Zone in Beijing is a dynamic blend of art, culture, and history. Explore its industrial-chic spaces filled with galleries, studios, and cafés, offering a unique glimpse into China's thriving contemporary art scene. A must-visit for art enthusiasts!

Creative and imaginative art district in Beijing. One of the highlights people should visit in Beijing. Many galleries, cafes and shops to explore. The area is quite big with many lanes to visit. Definitely bring your camera to get some good pictures

This is a great spot for tourists looking for mini souvenirs for family. Also cool art galleries, cafes, drinks, and music shops. This area is highly dedicated to artist and creative beings. Love this artisan area!

Perfect area to spend a day. Multiple restaurants and also you can find cuisines from different nations. Walls with graffiti, structure is like an abandoned industrial area which was later converted to commercialisation. You can go there in groups but must go at-least once.

A nice escape from the hustle and bustle of Beijing. The area is free to access and is dotted with beautiful wall art, graffiti, and modern art museums. Most of the museums are free while some require a small entrance fee. Although it takes about an hour to get to from the city center, it's a breath of fresh air to see a blend of Western and Chinese artwork and decor. There are little handicraft, DIY shops, and a plethora of modern cafes for you to sit and enjoy a tea or coffee in. Make sure to take the time to explore the area thoroughly as it's broken up into multiple art zones and doesn't just consist of the 798.

data.formatted_address: W95W+FXQ, Dongcheng, China, 100051
data.name: Tiananmen

reviews.text:
Tight security to enter, however a must see location to start day for a tour of The Forbidden City.

Wake up nice and early to see the Flag Raising, and walk through the gates to enter The Palace Museum.

When entering The Palace Museum there was a long line, so for timing wise make sure you go early. We found a tour guide that offered 100rmb per person (Chinese Guide) or 800rmb for 4 people person (English Guide).

Woke up bright and early to see the first flag raising ceremony of the month. It was a little hard to see with how many people there were, especially with everyone holding up their phones to record. Nevertheless, highly recommend going if you're able to wake up that early. Bring your passport - there are a LOT of checkpoints.

Advanced booking via wechat needed, passport needed, all bags and waters need to be stored in the Bag Deposit first. We'll, let's don't talk about politics, this is just someplace that holds my breath when I went up there and took the view.... anything else's were suddenly so tiny in view... and for one second, I could have been brainwashed by the redness/goldeneye up there. Entrance fee: 10 RMB.

One will need to walk through the famous front gate and two other gates to reach the palace. Strict security and every little extra visit such as going up to the terrace will require an additional reservation. Opposite the front gate is the Tiananmen Square. If you just want to take a close look at the front entrance with the portrait of Mao, take a bus that rides alongside the front gate.

Beautiful square and a historical site that is a must-see if or when in Beijing.

This is also the area to pass before passing the gates to The Forbidden City.

data.name: Long Corridor

reviews.text: The long corridor in the Summer Palace is an architectural marvel that captivates visitors with its grandeur and history. Stretching over 700 meters along the picturesque Kunming Lake, this corridor boasts intricately painted ceilings and vibrant hand-painted panels depicting Chinese mythology, landscapes, and historical events. As you stroll through, the cool breeze from the lake complements the tranquil ambiance, offering a serene escape from the bustling city. It's a must-visit destination for those seeking beauty, culture, and a glimpse into China's imperial past.

A long covered walkway with over 8000 intricate paintings depicting scenes from Chinese literary classics and old fables. There are also four octagonal pavilions connected by the corridor, each one with a theme and more elaborate artwork (don't miss the ceilings). Worth taking a stroll through.
Old architecture, must see the ancient china.

Follow the crowd...
Well worth the visit despite the swarm/hordes of tourists! One of the sights that should definitely not be missed. Take a look around and try to relax but crowds can become manic... All part of the experience.
This is behind Summer Palace in Beijing China a very beautiful place and huge area, We walked for 2 hours and still could not cover the entire park.

Free to visit with your Passport. A nice collection of diverse art. We enjoyed

The National Art Museum of China is located at 1 Wusi Ave, Dongcheng District, Beijing, People's Republic of China. It is one of the largest art museums in China, and is funded by the Ministry of Culture. The construction of the museum started in 1958, and concluded in 1962.
Foreigners can just show up at ticket office (with passport !) and they will let you in without a booking. Very helpful security person staff to explain this beside office on English.

data.formatted_address: China, Bei Jing Shi, Chao Yang Qu, 民族园路1号 邮政编码: 100017
data.name: China Ethnic Museum

reviews.text: Big museum

Beijing Chinese Ethnic Park is a large-scale ethnic cultural garden integrating the traditional architecture, ethnic customs, song and dance performances, crafts and ethnic cuisine of China's ethnic minorities.
The whole park covers an area of ​​45 hectares and is divided into North and South Parks. The North Park has been completed and opened, covering an area of ​​20 hectares. There are sixteen ethnic villages built in Beiyuan, including Tibetan, Miao, Yi, Dong, Taiwan Gaoshan, Korean, Buyi, Hani, Qiang, Dai, Jingpo, Daur, Ewenki, Oroqen, and Hezhe ethnic groups and other scenic spots. The park has the largest cast-iron sculpture in China, as well as simulated tropical banyan forests, water caves, soil forests, Panlong Waterfall, Cangyuan rock paintings, Alishan sacred trees, etc.
South Park is under construction and mainly includes large-scale facilities such as the Ethnic Museum and Sculpture Square, as well as more than 20 ethnic villages. All buildings adopt a 1:1 ratio to truly reproduce the cultural relics of each ethnic group. When visiting ethnic villages, tourists can also appreciate and participate in the songs, dances, festivals, productions and customs of various ethnic groups. Performing activities such as athletics and skills, so as to gain the unique cultural and artistic enjoyment of the Chinese nation.
Beautiful place but a little neglected. It could become a top tourist attraction due to the quality of information and incredible structure and facilities

data.formatted_address: China, Bei Jing Shi, Chao Yang Qu, 北辰东路5号 邮政编码: 100101
data.name: China Science and Technology Museum

reviews.text:
The ticket  booking process was quite a hassle.  You must book a visit via wechat mini program which requires chinese mobile phone number, therefore I have to use one of the travel agency to book the tickets for us.

The museum have many hilights such as replica of Tian Gong space station and a Chang Er spacecraft. We also booked the 4D movie which was nice especially if you have yound children.

A good place for kids, not that informative for adults but you should take your children to this place as they will enjoy a lot. It's a multi storey building with each floor dedicated to some particular field of science and technology. Also, at ground floor there is a place for very small kids, not sure but may be kids upto 6 years can go in there. Furthermore, there is a 4D cinema that you can enjoy at this museum with a separate ticket
Great place to bring kids to keep them entertained and learn about science and technology.
Designed for family visitors. Combined with a well-equipped movie theater.

It's a great museum to see concepts with some practical demo machines. But the depth is lacking for persons with the knowledge. Also 80 percent of text is in Chinese. Be prepared to use your image translator.

data.formatted_address: China, Bei Jing Shi, Xi Cheng Qu, 复兴门外大街16号 邮政编码: 100035
data.name: Capital Museum

reviews.text:
My first stop for the day is the Beijing Capital Museum. This is one of the best museums you can visit here in Beijing. The place is pretty big and you will find that they is a good number of tourists that come here. There is a long queue at the entrance as everyone is required to go through security checks before entering. Lighters and Tripods and not permitted here, so you will have to dispose of any lighters that you may have, and also deposit your tripod to collect when you are done. Tickets here are free, and all you need to do is present your passport or ID at the ticket booth.

There are a total of 4 floors of items and relics that you can look at. Most of the relics that they have here are in very good condition and are displayed very nicely for you to see. They have a section on buddha relics as well which I particularly enjoyed. but generally the whole museum is worth dedicating at least an hour to slowly appreciate.

Everything in China is huge and flashy.  The Capital Museum is no exception.  It is very modern and has a very diverse collection of artifacts. One day will not be enough to go around it, let alone to pay attention to the ancient artifacts on display.
Great artifacts here.  Good Chinese opera masks.  Very clean.  Free entrance. Worth a visit.
this is located near subway and recently i visited moreover this is very good place to spend time. there are many differnt uniques old masterpieces there.
The museum was not open according to its official opening schedule. No explanations or information given

data.formatted_address: 142 Xi Wai Da Jie, Xi Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100044
data.name: Paleozoological Museum of China

reviews.text: 3-floors perfect for dinosaur and animal loving kids and adults. To pay, they do accept cash but prefer WeChat or some other Chinese app foreigners don’t usually have. The fossils are very cool, as well as a giant fish that looks fake but is real. And while isn’t as big as say the Museum of Geology which also contains dinosaur exhibits, you can see everything quickly in 45min if going fast. If they had a bit more interactive bits it’d be a 5/5, but I’d still recommend it highly as is!
We loved it and it's worth it, we just wished it would have the English translation too, or someone translating
A really good place for people who wants to learn about the evolution of life on earth. Definitely worth a visit!

Small and cozy museum next to the planetarium. Although the museum is small, only 3 floors high, and a bit expensive (20 yuan for one child), the  things displayed were amazing! I saw lots of dinosaur bones (obviously), and fossilized dinosaur poop and eggs :3 I even saw a preserved coelacanth! The gift shop was terrible, but they sold REAL fossils for only 200 yuan! The movie was nice and interesting, but the kids were screaming and crawling everywhere, unfortunately.

you might find it challenging as english only speaker but it s all pretty obvious and translated in english and tickets are very cheap including the panda house especially if it s your first time seeing a panda and there around five or six. there is also a polar bear and a big beautiful lake and an elephant and some birds and also a huge aquarium which you need to pay extra to access. that s all i got to see in the little 2 hours that I stayed there because I had to catch a flight out of PEK.

reviews.text: I really enjoyed this museum. It’s on the 37th floor in Shanghai Tower. Purchase the add on ticket when purchasing the tower ticket. Beautiful displays of ceramics, gold pieces and other dynasty treasures.

Pros:
Cats in the courtyard are cute and well kept.
Modern and well designed exteriors

Cons:
Actual exhibit is mediocre at best.  The museum itself is small, about 7000 sqft total, and it’s variety of artifacts somewhat lacking. The style of artifacts here aren’t unique to this museum.

The admissions fee is steep: $100

Ticket seller doesnt honor student discounts if they think you look / are “too old”.  While the museum touts a discount for students at the undergrad level or lower, it doesn’t actually honor this.  When I showed my undergrad student ID, the admissions lady informed me I’m too old to be an undergrad student.  She denied that students can take a break for a couple years before commuting to college.

Overall:
I wouldn’t recommend this museum to anyone and I wouldn’t come back.  Instead, I’d recommend visiting the public museums in Beijing instead, which are not only more affordable, but also exhibits a greater variety of artifacts

reviews.text: Recommended by the local friend to come here. I don’t see much tourists here. No tickets were needed if you’re not watching the IMAX theater here. It’s great for families with kids looking for something to do in Beijing. Full length led screen from bottom to top. Also read up on the Chinese film exhibits and history. Some exhibits were close for maintenance and some look rather dated. But the giant led screen makes up for all of it! My toddler absolutely loves it.

Whenever you visit Beijing don't forget to travel to the China national film museum too although you like or dislike it.

For me?
It's worth my time to learn and fall in love more after visiting particularly in excitement about their film technology which amazingly develops so fast.

And yes I feel positive and surprised so much indeed.

We went to see a movie on the full IMAX screen - which was a wonderful experience - and also got to see some of the museum beforehand. I’m a professional filmmaker so it was cool to see old equipment from throughout history, included some I learned on myself. About the cinema: nowadays, the scaled-down “IMAX” in mall theaters has become most people’s idea of what the format is, but if you have a chance to see a film on the true 5-story tall screen, go! I’m a snob about picture and sound quality, and both here were excellent. One note is that if you want to see the entire museum beforehand, check the hours and make sure to get there in time. Various exhibitions close early. Going back this weekend to see Oppenheimer and can’t wait!

reviews.text: Anyone with an interest in railways, this huge place is a must see! It has an incredible collection of locomotives. They had all run on China railways, many Chinese-built but some were manufactured in Japan (during the War), Britain, Romania, and many other countries. The range of size from small to huge and from steam to electric and diesel is amazing! And the display documentation (in English and Chinese) gives more information than I've seen in another train museum.  There is also Chairman Mao's personal train in full (pay extra to put on blue booties and walk through).  If you love trains, it is worth flying to Beijing specially from anywhere in the world just to spend a day there!

This is the "Dong Jiao" exhibition hall of the China Railway Museum. Although the location is relatively remote, it is definitely worth it. There are many types of locomotives and vehicles from the Qing Dynasty to the beginning of the 21st century. It is a paradise for train lovers.

Nearest bus stop is less than 1km but more than 500m away.

reviews.text:

The vast amount of guns on display, including many rarities is something that anyone passionate about military history and the history of China would appreciate. The exhibits also help in introducing and understanding Chinese culture and modern history, as the focus of the museum is the very events which have made the China of today.

Do take time when visiting as it is a very large museum. Booking is as, as of time of writing, limited to online (no walk ins) and reservations must be made. I recommend utilising WeChat and finding sellers who pre book the tickets and can guarantee you a slot.

Unfortunately most text is Chinese only. But well worth a visit. The upper gallery was closed (small arms, uniforms). Don't miss the artillery/tanks in the basement.

data.formatted_address: 9255+7VX, 216 Sheng Dao, 八达岭镇 Yan Qing Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 102112
data.name: The Great Wall Museum of China

reviews.text: The Great wall of Beijing is one of the most iconic landmarks in China, and a must-see for any visitor. The wall stretches for over 21,000 kilometers and was built over centuries to protect the Chinese empire from invaders. The wall is divided into several sections, each with its own history and features. One of the most popular and accessible sections is the Badaling Great wall, which is located about 80 kilometers northwest of Beijing. The Badaling Great wall has a well-preserved entrance that dates back to the Ming dynasty and offers stunning views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The entrance is also equipped with modern facilities, such as cable cars, restaurants, souvenir shops, and museums. The entrance fee is 40 yuan per person, and the opening hours are from 6:30 am to 6:00 pm. To get to the Badaling Great wall entrance from Beijing, you can take a bus, a train, or a taxi. The bus number 877 departs from Deshengmen bus station every 10 minutes and takes about an hour to reach the entrance. The train departs from Beijing North Railway Station every 20 minutes and takes about 40 minutes to reach Badaling Railway Station, which is a short walk from the entrance. The taxi fare is about 200 yuan and takes about an hour and a half to reach the entrance.

This site is available via a city bus. A guided bus tour is unnecessary. The railcar back down is gravity powered, cheap and driven by a volunteer. The tourist area at the bottom needs redevelopment, but the actual Great Wall is well maintained.

The Great Wall of Badaling is approximately 80 km away from Beijing. It is a quite easy to visit Badaling Great Wall via metro (using line 13 and then transfer to S2) from Beijing. The cost of S2 is less than 7 yuan in single ride.
this location is not existing
Gorgeous great Wall! But you got to be strong enough to reach North 8 building by foot.

data.formatted_address: China, 北京市昌平区小汤山镇59P7+FH4 邮政编码: 102211
data.name: China Aviation Museum

reviews.text: Pretty cool museum with a rather spacious outdoor area (which is free) and some exhibition halls. Displays mostly vintage Chinese/Soviet airplanes. You can also rent cute little golf carts that are super fun to get around with. Got there via Shahe University Park Subway and then took a Didi. Not sure that is the best way.

Great place to see old Chinese PLAAF aircraft. A bit busy on weekends but free admission. Many aircraft are in excellent condition considering they are outside and there are tons of old MIGs. That said, some have taken a lot of abuse from guests and show dents, broken windows, etc. Especially the helicopters. Sad that people can't just enjoy them without touching but this is China.

The major disappointment arises from the fact that the best displays are inside and were all locked and closed. We tried to ask if the hangar and cave were just closed for the day but not a single person spoke any English to explain. Even the Tourist Information office. We attempted to use Google translate but still couldn't get an answer about the best closed bits.

There was a sign written in Chinese on both the hangar (PLAAF history) and the mountain tunnel that apparently holds aircraft from the first 100 years of the PLAAF. One kind guest tried to explain that it's closed but we never figured out why.

The PLAAF uniform museum was padlocked as was the simulator experience. Basically, just wander around the outside aircraft for a couple hours and leave. Disappointing after a long expensive drive from the city.
Must come for aviation enthusiasts free entry just show passport for registration public transit is available

*Bunker exhibition area is currently closed.*
The bunker system which houses western/NATO aircraft such as the F-5, F-104, etc is currently closed and the reopen date is unknown.

You will see lots of J-2s (MiG-15) J-4s (MiG-17), J-6s (MiG-19), J-7IIs (Variant of early MiG-21), J-7Es, J-7Ds (Late MiG-21 with belly mounted 23 mms), J-8s, J-8Bs, Q-5As, and Q-5Ls. The museum literally has rows upon rows of the aforementioned aircraft for exhibit. There are also a few more noteworthy aircraft such as the KJ-1 AWACS, whose replica is at the museum and is the only example of the aircraft left in the world, and an early model of the J-10 inside the building behind the "Heroes' Avenue", which sits parallel to the row including the Il-28, KJ-1 and Tu-4. There is also a field with Mi-4s and some additional Q-5s and J-8s tucked away behind the C-47s on display.

In conclusion, a large museum but the closure of the Bunker system significantly reduced the variety of aircraft on display.
Slightly far away from city and not easy to get there . But not to be missed , if in Beijing.

reviews.text: Incredible museum filled with Bronze Age attifants - I was in awe!

I wasn't offered an audio, but on the name plates of the displayed pieces, there was a headset symbol. It's a compact museum specifically focused on recovered relics from overseas. The main showcase is the 4 zodiac fountainheads (pig, monkey, tiger,  and ox) that were ransacked from the Old Summer Palace in 1860. This gives interest to going to the Old Summer Palace. If you are interested in seeing the 3 other recovered fountainheads: rat and rabbit are housed in the National Museum, and the horse is housed in the Capital Museum. reviews.text: It's a 350 m walk (5 min) from exit B of the Fuchengmen metro station on line 2. Free admittance. The Lu Xun museum was bare. I was expecting many artifacts and details from Lu Xun's life. Probably it is in transition. Currently there is an oddly placed exhibit on Liaonan shadow puppet theater. You can only enter the courtyard and backyard of the residence. The windows are clean to allow a view into the buildings. It's a quick visit that you can pair with visiting Miaoying Temple (White Stupa Temple)

This portrait that appears everywhere in the museum is very interesting. There seems to be another one painted by his friend that is very abstract. Lu Xun commented that the painting is very good😆
It’s a place where you can relax and visit with not many people, but when I think of Lu Xun’s first wife, Ms. Zhu Dan, emm, I still can’t fall in love with the literati of the Republic of China. Although they can write classic poems and articles, they are all scumbags emotionally. Lu Xun and Dai Wangshu Xu Zhimo...

The Lu Xun Museum in Beijing consists of an exhibition hall and his former residence.
Lu Xun's former residence is an exquisite courtyard house. It was Lu Xun's last and most important residence in Beijing. The courtyard contains three south rooms, four north rooms, and east and west wing rooms. The most famous one is the "tiger tail" that Lu Xun connected behind the north room. This small room of less than ten square meters was designed by Mr. Lu Xun himself. As his studio and bedroom, it can ensure the lighting time and the view. The view of the garden behind. "In my back garden, you can see two trees outside the wall, one is a jujube tree, and the other is also a jujube tree." Lu Xun wrote about these two jujube trees in "Autumn Night", although they are no longer there But the white lilacs he planted by himself are still blooming quietly in the backyard.
The Lu Xun Museum is larger in area and is divided into two floors: ground and underground. It has collected more than 30,000 precious cultural relics, including Lu Xun's anatomy notes when he was studying medicine in Sendai, and the only copy of "The True Story of Ah Q". The remaining manuscripts, the collection of books and rubbings collected by Lu Xun, etc. The exhibition layout of the museum is divided into different chapters according to Mr. Lu Xun's geographical footprint, from Shaoxing to Japan, from Beijing to Shanghai, which is very clear.

A short walk from Fuchengmen Station on Line 2. As you walk along Fuchenmen Nei Main Street, you will see a signboard. Turn left and you'll see a gate. Security is on the left, so buy your ticket at the counter on the right. It's supposed to be 1RMB, but on the day I went (September 24, 2016), it was free. There is a main museum (first floor and basement), special exhibitions, Beijing home, etc. Here is Lu Xun's best writing (in Japanese).

reviews.text:
A black shop, a black shop, this is a black shop, tourists must not be fooled! !
Passengers who come to Beijing by taxi should be careful and read the travel guide before setting off to avoid being deceived.
It was the first time for the four of us to visit Beijing. When we took a taxi from the Forbidden City back to the hotel near Beijing Station at 4:30 pm on the first day, the driver enthusiastically talked about a lot of attractions in Beijing, among which "Huguang Guild Hall" was definitely a must-see, and looked disgusted as to why we hadn't heard of it. Go see old alleys, crosstalk performances, taste Beijing tea, and experience old Beijing. If you haven’t been there, you’ve come to Beijing in vain. Tickets are 160 all-inclusive. Today is the last day for the exhibition. If you don’t go, you’ll miss it. But we thought the tickets were too expensive and refused to go. Then the driver suggested that we take the subway and take us directly to a nearby subway station to drop us off because of the serious traffic jams on the road. We had no doubts. (It turns out that the driver doesn’t want to take us, so we can quickly find the next driver)
On the second day, we took a taxi from the Temple of Heaven and returned to the hotel around 4:30 pm. This time, the driver explained that a foreign head of state was here, and traffic control was implemented outside, and cars could not drive through. He suggested that we play for a while longer. It was better to go back at 5:30 and the transportation was better (we believed it). We also recommended going to the Huguang Guild Hall. I kept saying that it was a must-go. I kept saying that I could learn more about and experience Beijing by seeing the old alleys, drinking tea, and riding rickshaws. Suddenly, I changed I was stupid (forgetting that the driver said it was the last day the day before yesterday, oh my god! I'm so stupid.), so I let the driver take me there.

What is the legendary must-see old Beijing like? The answer is: The pit is huge.
First I bought tickets for 160 per person, and then the waiter had a bad attitude. She explained the courtyard house for five minutes, then led us to listen to cross talk for five minutes, and then went to wait for the rickshaw outside. After waiting for almost ten minutes, more and more customers were waiting. Nearly 20 people were waiting in line for the bus. The bus finally arrived, and at the same time, Many rickshaws came to take us there together, so the rickshaws rode around the so-called old alleys for a few times, and got off in less than five minutes (getting off the bus was not at the same point as getting off the bus). Where is the so-called old Beijing? What about the alley? I didn't see anything! I feel cheated now. After we got off the bus, we walked to the alley opposite to see the works of famous calligraphers and painters they claimed. On the way, everyone complained that they felt cheated, only to find out that everyone was brought here by taxi, with a lot of excuses. It's quite popular. Some of the tickets for this museum usually cost 260 yuan. If there is a discount of 160 yuan, you can go in and see. Some of them recommend taking a rickshaw for an hour and explaining the old alley in detail. When we arrived at the so-called calligraphy exhibition, it was just a few calligraphy and paintings, and the introduction of a few calligraphers we didn’t know. So we made a request to complain, but the attitude of the service staff was extremely bad and they rushed us to the next destination (teahouse). Half of us (about ten) refused to go and asked to return to the club to argue, and the other half followed us. Drive to the tea house. After we argued many times, the calligraphy shop employee took us back to the clubhouse. Oh my God! The guild hall turned out to be less than 300 meters away around the corner, but the rickshaw took me around for a few minutes. This is not a lie! Finally, when the staff couldn't stop us, we all walked into the lobby of the club together and asked to talk to the person in charge in the lobby.
The person in charge took us to the side and asked for a refund on the grounds that we were not satisfied with the service.
