data.name: Zhoukoudian Site Museum

reviews.text: Interesting and entertaining setup of the World Heritage side. All signs and descriptions in Chinese and English. Very clean and properly maintained.

Peking Man Site at Zhoukoudian is a Pleistocene hominid site on the North China Plain. This site lies about 42 km south-west of Beijing and is at the juncture of the North China Plain and the Yanshan Mountains. Adequate water supplies and natural limestone caves in this area provided an optimal survival environment for early humans. Scientific work at the site is still under way. So far, ancient human fossils, cultural remains and animal fossils from 23 localities within the property dating from 5 million years ago to 10,000 years ago have been discovered by scientists. These include the remains of Homo erectus pekinensis, who lived in the Middle Pleistocene (700,000 to 200,000 years ago), archaic Homo sapiens of about 200,000–100,000 years ago and Homo sapiens sapiens dating back to 30,000 years ago. At the same time, fossils of hundreds of animal species, over 100,000 pieces of stone tools and evidence (including hearths, ash deposits and burnt bones) of Peking Man using fire have been discovered.

As the site of significant hominid remains discovered in the Asian continent demonstrating an evolutionary cultural sequence, Zhoukoudian is of major importance within the worldwide context. It is not only an exceptional reminder of the prehistoric human societies of the Asian continent, but also illustrates the process of human evolution, and is of significant value in the research and reconstruction of early human history.
The most famous hominid site and museum. Located beside a tranquil village not far from the city. Fair price and easy to park.

Unfortunately  late patrons spolied the start.  27 of the 31 participants  got to the tour bus on time.  Almost two hours late we left for our adventure, andry, hungry, and anxious.

The tour itself was wonderful and Lisa was an incredible guide with an incredible knowledge of Beijing, the Great Wall, and China.  We learned so much from her that if mitigated the problem with waiting.

If you have signed up to be there by 9 am and the Cruise Ship has given you first passage off the boat before any others - you should be on time!  If you do take this tour please respect your fellow passengers and make sure you depart the cruise ship on time.

The company is not limited to Beijing. I found them on the web and arranged a day-trip to Suzhou while I was in Shanghai last week. Vivian helped me book and pay for the tour from the US and Chris was my awesome tour guide for the day.

I was collected from (and returned to) my Shanghai (Pudong) hotel for the lengthy drive to Suzhou. We stopped at The Humble Administrator's Garden, had lunch, Bao'en Temple (Beisi Pagoda),  Cold Mountain Temple,  Tiger Hill and walked along one of the streets lining the canal. Chris is knowledgeable, friendly and speaks excellent English.

Had I used the hotel-provided Suzhou tour, I would have paid twice the amount and been part of a group.

Terrible experience with them and cannot recommend them because not only did they threaten us with a lawsuit for writing our reviews but they refused to honor their own refund policies. We are in litigation with them now but you are not protected as an American citizen.  This is not an American friendly company and all they want is your money and interested in your travel experience.

data.formatted_address: W93X+R3X Tiananmen Square, 前门 Dong Cheng Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100051
data.name: Monument to the People's Heroes

reviews.text: The Monument to the People's Heroes is a majestic obelisk that commemorates the heroes of China's revolutionary struggles from the 19th to the 20th centuries. It stands proudly in the southern part of Tiananmen Square, facing the Mausoleum of Mao Zedong. The monument is adorned with bas-reliefs that depict eight major historical events, such as the Opium War, the Xinhai Revolution, and the War of Resistance Against Japan. The monument also bears inscriptions by Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai, expressing eternal glory and gratitude to the people's heroes.
Came at sunrise very beautiful!

Center area of a much larger and very important historical area for China. I was there for the 70th anniversary celebration in October of 2019. The area was VERY interesting and had hundreds of photo opportunities.
Centre of Tiananmen Square. Big column. Very imposing.

The Monument to the People's Heroes (Chinese: 人民英雄纪念碑; pinyin: Rénmín Yīngxióng Jìniànbēi) is a ten-story obelisk that was erected as a national monument of China to the martyrs of revolutionary struggle during the 19th and 20th centuries. It is located in the southern part of Tiananmen Square in Beijing, to the north of Mausoleum of Mao Zedong. The monument was built in accordance with a resolution of the First Plenary Session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference adopted on November 30, 1949, with construction lasting from August 1952 to May 1958. The architect of the monument was Liang Sicheng, with some elements designed by his wife, Lin Huiyin. The civil engineer, Chen Zhide (陈志德) was also instrumental in realizing the final product.

reviews.text:

The museum is small and can be quickly viewed in less than an hour. The permanent exhibits are organized well and display a few English signs. The collection is sparse with a few examples on enamels, jade carving, lacquer ware carving, ivory carving, and wood carving. The permanent exhibits are housed along the outer buildings with no English signs to distinguish them from general rooms. reviews.text:
If you like architecture especially brick architecture you have to come here. The highlight of this place is the architecture and it's garden. The art gallery is rather limited. If you love taking photos, this is a photographer's heaven.

The garden in the back is a must visit. There is a Cafe & restaurant at the back overlooking the pond with outdoor seating. Simple menus but if the weather is nice the outdoor seating is a great place to spend an afternoon.

One of the most beautiful contemporary art museums I’ve ever been to. The exhibition is a little small, but carefully curated. Many famous artists and thought provoking works. The garden behind the gallery is well worth exploring too especially if you love architecture.
Getting here through the subway was a long walk, so I recommend taking the bus or taxi once you arrive.

Must-see if you are into architecture/the arts! The building alone is worth the trip out there in the middle of nowhere. The quality of the content obviously depends on the artists on exhibit at the time of your visit.

Currently (SEP18) the Andreas Mühe exhibit is highly recommended. The quality of his photography goes under your skin (maybe I am being partial: My German up-bringing certainly helped me understand his often very German subject matter).

Anyway, go go go. So far I have been very disappointed by what Beijing has to offer. But this museum is top notch. It would even befit a sophisticated city like Tokyo.

Nice interesting space designed by Renown scholar Dong yugan. Using large amount of red bricks, the museum achieved a certain nostalgic spatial experiences and played quite masterfully with light/shadow, craftsmanship. It also has a permanent installation by Olafur Elliasson. Tickets are expensive, 130 rmb, so prepare your student id if you have any.... The traffic here however is terrible terrible, far away from any public transportation. Your only traffic means here is to taxi, which takes about 20-30mins to a subway station.

I think this place is ok. It’s a bit over rated / over hyped by those Instagrammers so I was here to check it out. The architectures in the courtyard behind the main exhibition were more interesting than the exhibition itself... parking is limited so you might want to come early. The entrance fee is a bit steep for what you actually can see in the museum... not sure if I would recommend this place but if you want to post something on Instagram yeah maybe this is a good place to get some pictures...

data.formatted_address: X6R6+G8G, Xiang Shan Nan Lu, Hai Dian Qu, Bei Jing Shi, China, 100093
data.name: Beijing Botanical Garden Tourist Service Center

reviews.text: Nice place to be close to nature

This is the Beijing Botanical Garden of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, which is very unique. As soon as you enter the door, there is a pond and a waterfall. There are lotus flowers in the summer and sometimes inflatable play balls. There are several greenhouses on the north side with many tropical plants. Here are the branches of the Bodhi tree when Sakyamuni became the Buddha, which were given to Premier Zhou by the leaders of India. To the south is the forested fruit tree area. There is an area of ​​medicinal plants on the east side. There is a large pond in the middle, which is an aquatic plant area. I have lived here for several years and accompanied my daughter here for two years. See flowers in spring, fish in summer, enjoy leaves in autumn, and skate in winter. Here, I caught hedgehogs, picked walnuts, gathered fireflies, and played with green snakes. Here, you can take your children to crawl across the grass, climb high branches, swing on the swings, and let the rabbits go. Everywhere is full of memories and joy.

The Beijing Botanical Garden of the Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences is divided into an arboretum, a perennial flower garden, a rose garden, a peony garden, a herbal garden, a crape myrtle garden, a wild fruit tree resource area, an environmentally friendly plant area, an aquatic plant area, a rare and endangered plant area, and tropical and subtropical plant exhibitions. There are more than 10 exhibition areas and exhibition rooms including greenhouses. Perennial flower area, magnolia and peony area, tropical plant exhibition greenhouse, aquatic and vine area, herbal garden, crape myrtle garden, rose garden, environmentally friendly plant area, wild fruit tree resource area, rare and endangered plant area, lilac area, shell area, naked seeds Floral area.

reviews.text: I visited Baiwangshan (百望山) on a Monday in December and there was virtually no one else there. It is a mountainous park with many different paths, some are paved and suitable for wheelchairs while others are steep hiking trails with scree and steps. The routes are well marked with maps placed at regular intervals. You can spend many hours exploring the pavilions, memorials, statues, and towers situated along the trails. From the top, the view is quite magnificent. Admission fee is 6 yuan.

reviews.text: Although not well known, Dayunhe Forest Park is located where the Grand Canal enters Beijing and is a National Park. The park features cycle and walking paths on both sides of the river and is excellently maintained. Owing to the huge size of the park, the visitors are well spread out so it is not crowded. As the Grand Canal is now used to bring drinking water to Beijing, the water quality in the river is excellent and there is a large quantity of fish and water birds. I really enjoyed spending the day cycling at this park as it was easy to escape from the crowds and get lost in nature, something that it is not possible to do at most of Beijing’s more famous parks.
The air, water, trees and the whole environment is so wonderful for riding and wandering
Beautiful place for recreation and suitable for whole family.

A large park in the eastern suburbs of Beijing, next to the North Canal. The park area is very large, with a large proportion of green space. The scenery is very beautiful, with green plants, ponds, ornamental boats, various recreational facilities, flowers, birds, fish and insects, it is hard to imagine. For such a "complete" park, there is still no need for admission. It only costs 10 yuan to take a viewing boat to the other side from here, and 15 yuan for a round trip, but you must pay attention to the return time. If you miss the last boat, you will have to make a long circuit to get back. The park also has power-assisted bicycles, which you can rent to conveniently explore the entire park. In the eastern suburbs of Beijing, there is such a beautiful park, and the people around it are really happy.
There is only one suburban park in Beijing with a very beautiful environment. It has many green plants and a large area of ​​water, which is a natural oxygen bar!

The Chinese Ethnic Park is located in the southwest of the Asian Games Village in Beijing, covering an area of ​​50 hectares. Construction began in 1992. The North Park was completed and opened on June 18, 1994, and the South Park was completed and opened on September 29, 2001. There are 36 ethnic villages in the park, as well as ethnic museums, ethnic exhibition halls, sculpture squares and several natural landscapes. There are 16 ethnic villages in the North Park, including the largest cast-iron temple in China, as well as simulated tropical banyan forests, water caves, earth forests, Panlong Waterfall, Alishan sacred trees and Cangyuan rock paintings. The ethnic minority villages all adopt a 1:1 ratio. The pavilions, buildings and houses are scattered along the mountains and rivers. According to the ethnic minority style, the cultural relics of each ethnic group are truly reproduced.

data.formatted_address: 4 Jing Shan Qian Jie, Dong Cheng Qu, China, 100009
data.name: Meridian Gate

reviews.text: The Meridian Gate, known as 午门 (Wu Men) in Chinese, stands prominently as the southern entrance to Beijing's Forbidden City. This architectural masterpiece, dating back to the Ming Dynasty, is a marvel of imperial grandeur and symbolism. Its central archway was reserved exclusively for the emperor's use, emphasizing his divine status. Flanked by two smaller gates, the Meridian Gate showcases intricate wooden carvings and vibrant colors, reflecting traditional Chinese design. Beyond its aesthetic significance, the gate played a role in imperial ceremonies. Today, it serves as a key attraction, providing visitors a glimpse into the rich history and regal splendor of ancient China.

Meridian Gate (午门 Wu Men): The Southern entrance to the Forbidden City, the Meridian Gate is an impressive sight. Its five towers resemble a majestic flying phoenix. As you approach, you’ll notice ticket booths just before the gate, where you can purchase your entrance ticket. I recommend buying your ticket online to avoid queues. Surprisingly, no physical ticket is issued; instead, you can simply scan your passport, and the system recognizes your valid ticket. Arrive early to beat the crowds, especially during peak seasons.

The Meridian Gate marks the beginning of your journey into the heart of the Forbidden City. Once inside, you’ll discover a meticulously maintained palace complex, with its distinctive architectural style. The entire Forbidden City is symmetrically aligned along the Meridian axis, making this gate a crucial entry point for exploring the historical wonders within.

Remember to capture some photos of this iconic gateway during your visit!

Amazing architecture, this is actually the main entrance to The Palace Museum so if you want to skip Tiananmen Square and all the tour groups or if you’re tight on time I recommend to walk around and enter The Palace Museum from here.

Make sure you purchase tickets in advance as ticket numbers are limited daily.

reviews.text: The Peking Man site at Zhoukoudian on the outskirts of Beijing was discovered in the 1920s and has yielded prolific fossil remains of the archaic human species Homo erectus, dated to approximately 500,000 years ago. An active program of research is still being conducted at Zhoukoudian by the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Academia Sinica. Visitors can tour previously excavated localities as well as a museum which contains exhibits on the site's geology, paleontology, paleoanthropology and archaeology.

data.name: Zhenjue Temple

reviews.text: This pagode looks very nice in autumn with the big ancient trees there. Definitly worth a visit. The stone carving museum is a nice bonus.

This is a pretty well hidden place and as temples go, has two special attractions. One is the five pagoda structure in the middle, which is one of only two of such pieces of architecture in Beijing - the other being quite out of the way in the western hills. The truly unique thing about this place is the second, i.e. the stone carvings and sculptures museum that's located in this temple. Well worth a visit.

Near the zoo and the National Library. I have been here before, but never to this place. The more famous ones are the remaining Five Pagoda Temple and the big ginkgo tree next to it. It is very spectacular, especially in autumn. Here now It has become a stone carving art museum, and these stone carvings are also very informative.

Built in the ninth year of Chenghua in the Ming Dynasty (1473), it is commonly known as the Five Pagoda Temple Pagoda. It is made of brick and is 18.6 meters long from north to south, 15.73 meters wide from east to west, and 17 meters high.

A museum displaying stone monuments and statues located on the north side of the Beijing Zoo. I visited many temples in Beijing, but Zhenjue Temple (Watago Temple) and Biyun Temple in Xiangshan Park were different from each other as you can see in the photo.

There is a Vajra Throne Tower in Zhenjue Temple. During the Yongle period of the Ming Dynasty, the Nepali monk Bandida came to Beijing and presented five golden Buddhas and a model of the Vajra Throne Pagoda to Emperor Yongle, so Emperor Yongle allowed him to build a Vajra Throne Pagoda according to this model in Zhenjue Temple. Chenghua of the Ming Dynasty It was completed in nine years. The pagoda is covered with Buddhist-themed carvings. It is a masterpiece of ancient Chinese architecture absorbing foreign architectural culture. It is also one of the few Ming Dynasty buildings in Beijing.

reviews.text:
Liuyin Park is a small but picturesque oasis in the middle of the city, with idyllic rural scenery. Though not very large, the park offers a variety of features such as lakes, flower gardens, small bridges, hillsides and even badminton courts. The park is alive with the sound of birds, including many mallard ducks and red shelducks swimming in the lake. Every spring, when the flowers bloom, wild ducks gather to breed on the wild duck island. In addition, there is a small teahouse in the park where you can enjoy tea around the stove. This park is a rare spot of green and tranquility in the midst of a bustling and noisy urban area. The park’s rural style is reminiscent of a village in the city.

The CCTV Tower in Beijing, also known as the CCTV Headquarters, is a prominent architectural landmark in Beijing, China. It's a striking skyscraper designed by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas and his firm OMA (Office for Metropolitan Architecture). The building is characterized by its unique and unconventional design, featuring two leaning towers connected by a horizontal section. The CCTV Tower is primarily used as the headquarters for China Central Television (CCTV) and has become an iconic symbol of modern architecture in Beijing. It's located in the central business district of the city, in the Chaoyang District.
